the year is 2009.
you just dropped out of college and moved home to start a band.
you are angsty and hungover and trying to figure out your life.
you bleach your hair on a whim using boxed bleach from CVS.
10 years later you‚Äôre waking up in your new home next to your dog. no hangover, no anxiety, your life pretty figured out. still doing that band you dropped out of college to start. growth is tight. and so is getting your hair professionally done.

1 year ago today I woke up with a horrible hangover and tears in my eyes and I told myself, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm done.‚Äù I did a pretty good job of making light of my problem with drugs and alcohol but it eventually reached a point where I knew something had to change. It hasn‚Äôt been easy but oh man has it been rewarding. I‚Äôve never felt more myself than I do today and I owe that to sobriety (and also therapy!) If you‚Äôre struggling, just know there is a way out.

Thank you to all of the people who have been there for me the past year of my life while I went through extreme changes, you know who you are. And to the fans who have been patient with me while I figure out how to navigate said changes- you better believe there‚Äôs plenty of songs that came out of this experience. I‚Äôm beyond grateful to be where I am today because a year ago, it didn‚Äôt seem possible. And not every day is easy, because that‚Äôs life, but every day is a new opportunity to do things differently and that rules. I‚Äôm basically a walking self help book now, so you better get used to it ‚ù§Ô∏èüôèüèª (üì∑ by my precious jewel @juanvigoda)

i‚Äôm 2 years sober today (and still out here partying it up in ridiculous outfits!!!) i‚Äôve never been good at sticking with things, but sobriety has been a journey worth sticking to. big ass love for my life today.

I hope I don‚Äôt come off as an ass... A woman just stopped me in the grocery store and told me that she had never seen a basket like mine.I told her that I have never NOT seen this type of basket in my grocery-shopping behavior.A few others chimed in saying that it was a very strange sight! WTF?A strange sight?I‚Äôm in a grocery store.It‚Äôs food.It got me thinking and really fired up...I hear in the news constantly, in legislative bodies debating and the public complaining out right bitching about healthcare costs, drug companies and doctors and what rising costs do to our society, our lives and our economy. I know our system isn‚Äôt great.Yet, the public poisons itself daily with bad food choices. Food is medicine and medicine is food. It‚Äôs a fact. If we want to see our healthcare system changed, be a healthier society- and it will. How does that sound? Logical right? I don‚Äôt mean to sound like a dick- or preachy but this is nuts: how is it, that grown professional people in a major American city have never seen a grocery basket full of normal&healthy foods that just all happen to be green or not processed.We‚Äôre so far down the rabbit hole of packaged and ‚Äúconvenient‚Äù foods that our society is paying the price&so is our future.No one in our government is helping us be healthier through education.Why would they?Sick people are GREAT for business...
It‚Äôs pretty simple:If you want to look well, feel well and BE well- just eat well. Obviously excersise as well, as much as you can.Everything else will start to fall into place.My mom raised me on no money&mostly as a single parent yet, she still ate well&exercised and it shaped my life.We make excuses why we can‚Äôt find the time to take care of ourselves and we end up past the point of no return... Why is that?How is it that we can‚Äôt see that:Happy and healthy people make a happy and healthy world.It‚Äôs hard to see that through a fog of prescription drugs, energy drinks&strong sleep aids. It‚Äôs hard I know, but its time to change. You wouldn‚Äôt put the wrong gas in your car, so why would you put wrong food in your body? We MUST take responsibility for what we put into our bodies starting now. We can do it.Ok.I‚Äôll stop.Thnks

Just found this: A season wrap on the Vampire Diaries, maybe Season 3,4or 5 I‚Äôm not sure. I took this in the mirror of Damon‚Äôs dressing room to remember how worn down I was but smiling- That‚Äôs a nebulizer I‚Äôm sucking on-shooting pharmaceutical hydrogen peroxide into my lungs to keep from collapsing from an infection. Supplements, oxygen chambers flying around like a maniac making a TV show and trying to build companies while building @isfofficial . Be careful. Ambition can be dangerous... I‚Äôve found this image and wanted to share it. We‚Äôve lost amazing men and women recently who really helped change the world but their bodies perished from the pressure and abuse of running too hard and not taking care of themselves. I‚Äôm humbly searching for that balance and I wish you all luck in finding it. Meditation helps, I use transcendental mediation or TM- it‚Äôs super easy. Just remember this- we don‚Äôt actually need much to live happy lives. We, as humans firmly believe more and more and more and more ‚Äúthings‚Äù will make us happy. Unfortunately they don‚Äôt make us happy. Our buying patterns just fuels economies ... Our kids deserve to grow up not seeing us staring at these little glowing devices in our hands. I hide around corners and under pillows so my little one doesn‚Äôt see it... Our babies need us present to teach them and to listen to them. It‚Äôs the only way to build a loving and sustainable society. At least that‚Äôs what I think- take it or leave it;)

I‚Äôll never forget the feeling of helplessness watching our communities here in California burn. I‚Äôm grateful that these destructive flames have stopped due to the hard work and risk of the men and women who fought them from the land and from the air. To our FIREFIGHTERS: We are so grateful for you today and everyday. We love and respect you immensely. To all of our Police and other the 1st responders, emergency professionals and volunteers that went in to save people, homes and animals we thank you from the deepest depths of our hearts. We thank each and every one of you to the stars and back. The @losangelesfiredepartment , you are among the greatest heroes on this planet and your bravery and commitment to protecting our state, our people and our creatures is so powerful and so appreciated. Thank you @lafdfoundation for supporting them. From my family to yours, we thank you all on this day. We can only hope that all those affected by natural disasters this year and in recent years find some happiness and a hug today. Hope is all we have to move forward in these terrible moments but together as community we are strong and can share smiles. I send you all love today and applaud your strength and courage to press on. May we start to talk more seriously about where the increasing number of violent hurricanes and fires, that are destroying our homes and communities are coming from and together pave a road to a more peaceful and less destructive future.
Happy Thanksgiving to all and may today not be about gluttonous consumption but gratitude for the simple things in life, the things that we need to survive: Family, friends and food.
With immense gratitude,
Ian Somerhalder
Mondays...

Me at 17 years old.
An America Eagle campaign in the summer of 1996. This was shot in the middle of no where on famous Route 66 at an old desert cafe in the California. How different 1996 was. I read books with an insatiable thirst for philosophy, history, science and nature as shadows lengthened in the sun. What a time. People talked and talked and talked about life on the streets, in parks, in restaurants and bars. It was a special time. The time before the smartphone. I often think about those times when our focus was experiencing moments and not broadcasting every single moment of our entire lives... there was so much clarity. I miss those times...

I have just been quietly off of social media mourning the loss of so much life on our planet happening around us. We are the same biological process as the planet. What we do to our world we do ourselves. The trees are the Earth‚Äôs lungs, oceans and rivers act as the world‚Äôs cardiovascular system carrying all of the vital nutrients to the world‚Äôs organs (the very things that give us life) The unnecessary and illegal man-made fires ripping through the Amazon (the vital lungs of our planet), Hurricane Dorian ripping through the Beautiful Bahamas and the South East on a path of destruction. Now Japan is telling us that they may have to dump enormous amounts of radioactive waste water into the ocean because they are running out of space to store it. Where DOES it end? I can‚Äôt be silent any longer... WE MUST stop the destruction and senseless slaughter of all that gives us life: RAIN FORESTS AND OCEANS. We can not afford to lose one more acre of forest, we can‚Äôt take any more storms and radioactive waste. HOW DO WE DO THIS? SOMEONE? #Repost @paulnicklen with @get_repost

The latest instalment of @biekedepoorter's long-running project, 'Agata', is going on show at @parisphotofair this week as part of the @huaweinextimage Awards stand.
.
The project started in November 2017, as a result of Magnum‚Äôs Live Lab in Paris. While in the French capital Depoorter was invited to visit an infamous strip club in the Pigalle district where she met Agata, a young dancer working at the club. Agata invited Depoorter back to her home and together they made the very first photographs in what was to become a years-long project. .
Earlier this year the pair travelled to Lebanon to continue the work, with the support of the @huaweinextimage Awards.

‚ÄúMy life as a photographer has consisted of many travels across the African continent, a land impregnated with unusual, peculiar things, where unexpected moments can happen.
.
This picture was taken late one night in Brazzaville, Congo, in a neighborhood restaurant in the Poto-Poto district. It was taken with my Leica, after a hard day of work, almost without my knowledge.
.
A shadow like that of a Chinese (or should I say African?) puppet, lends itself to the game. Solicited by this ephemeral shadow, the wall agrees to participate. It proposes and positions the eye and the eyebrow to reveal this fugitive, invented profile, by capturing these shadows, framed by arms.
.
A photograph passes from one hand to another, a souvenir exchanged‚Ä¶
.
It was Sunday, October 27, 1985.‚Äù - Guy Le Querrec
.

'This image, dating from 1976, was part of Erich Hartmann‚Äôs experimental efforts to incorporate into his pictures another dimension, Time, here presented as Motion. .
In the seemingly limitless space pictured‚Äìin reality the great hall of Grand Central Station‚Äìone woman stands still and apart in the foreground; perfectly placed at a middle distance is a package-carrying male figure. There are less than two days left only to buy this print from @raghurai.official in The Magnum Square Print Sale in Partnership with @aperturefnd! Shop the sale via the link in bio.
.
‚ÄúI was shooting in Mumbai city for a book project in 1996. I had heard of local trains arriving into the city with a human deluge that was unmeasurable, a flood of people who would then be dispersed to their places of work. Sure enough, I reached Churchgate railway station‚Äìthe busiest place in the heart of the city‚Äìat 8 a.m. I stood there in awe and amazement, with an unimaginable and overpowering feeling of the deluge. It took less than a minute for thousands of commuters to disappear. The platform was empty again until 3 or 4 minutes later, when more trains arrived to bring in another deluge. .
More than the crowds, I wanted to capture so many human bodies melting into each other and disappearing in a mad rush to get to their respective places of work. So I put my camera on a 5 foot-high switch box almost in the middle of the space between two tracks and exposed it at one-eighth of a second in order to capture the deluge. But those sitting on the benches reading the morning newspaper or waiting for someone remained still. This expression is visible anytime of the day in most metropolitan cities in India.‚Äù- @raghurai.official
.
PHOTO: Local commuters at Churchgate railway station. Mumbai, India. 1995.
.
¬© @raghurai.official/#MagnumPhotos
.
#MAGNUMSQUARE #Hidden #India #Mumbai #streetphotography #RaghuRai

Five years ago, however, I started working closer to home, embarking on a collaborative project with my wife and creative partner, Rebecca Norris Webb, on Brooklyn, where we live. After decades of wandering the world, I‚Äôve been pleased to find that the unexpected, the unknown, or the secret heart of the known may sometimes lie just around the corner in our home borough‚Äîlike this scene of a boy, half-hidden in the shadows, lost in his thoughts on Surf Avenue.‚Äù - @webb_norriswebb

Micha Bar-Am shares the story behind this unusual family portrait. The signed print is available this week only! Link in bio.
.
‚ÄúIn 1991, Iraq attacked Israel with Scud missiles over the course of six weeks. Israel, for the first time ever, refrained from retaliating, bowing to pressure from the United States, which was leading an offensive against Iraq. Because the missiles were capable of carrying chemical or biological warheads, Israelis were equipped with gas masks and instructed to seal off a room in their homes. Oddly, there was no solution for bearded men like myself, nor for pets, who could not wear the masks.
.
The day on which the first missile was launched the siren sounded and everybody gathered in the sealed room. I was ready to photograph it, with my equipment already in my car, when I heard the alarm, but as it was not clear yet whether the missile was ‚Äòconventional‚Äô or not, I decided to wait it out with my family‚Äìmy wife, our two sons, and our house cat. So I photographed them.
.
As it turned out, the warheads did not contain unconventional materials but the damage that the 39 missiles caused was severe. Most of them landed not far from our home and we could hear every explosion. By the way, today there is free distribution of special masks for bearded people and a special solution for pets.‚Äù- Micha Bar-Am
.
PHOTO: Family Portrait with Cat, Gulf War. Ramat Gan, Israel. 1991.
.
¬© #MichaBarAm/#MagnumPhotos
.

‚ÄúI was in Marrakech in 1986 during the Folklore Festival. Sitting on a dirt wall, there was a group of girls waiting to perform. As soon as they saw me taking pictures, they started hiding, covering their faces with their hands, then uncovering them slightly to look at me, then covering them again. It was like a game of seduction and, though they were quite young, they already seemed to know that to hide and to show were the basic rules of the game. They kept playing at it for a little while, laughing loudly. It would have been great to have the soundtrack with this image.‚Äù- Harry Gruyaert
.
PHOTO: Marrakech, Morocco. 1986.
.

Magnum nominee @chiyin_sim shares an image and personal text in response to the theme of 'Hidden'. This signed print is available until midnight EST tonight (November 1) on shop.magnumphotos.com. Once it's gone, it's gone! Link in bio.
.
'In 2017, while working on an exhibition commission on nuclear weapons for the Nobel Peace Prize, I applied for permission to visit the vast Nevada Air Force Base Complex‚Äìwhich is known for its lunar landscape, a result of all the nuclear weapons tests carried out there‚Äìbut we were turned down. I was forced to be ‚Äòoutside looking in,‚Äô driving along its perimeter and trying to metaphorically see what was hidden beyond those mountains. For the exhibition commission, I created a series of diptychs comparing American Cold War-era nuclear landscapes with present-day North Korean ones. Indeed, I was also kept out of the North Korean plants, and had to photograph from the Chinese side of their shared border, at the closest points to Pyongyang‚Äôs known nuclear and military sites.
.
In a similar way to other landscape imagery in my practice, the photograph‚Äìoften taken to be, by nature, evidential‚Äìis almost counter-evidential in this case. Nothing is laid out in plain sight. These landscapes can be read with some imagination, to ‚Äòsee‚Äô what lies beneath, beyond.' - @chiyin_sim

PHOTOS: Nevada, USA. November 2017.
.
¬© @chiyin_sim/#MagnumPhotos
.

The elderly of Mosul, Iraq are far too acquainted with war. Every decade since 1920, the city has been involved in conflict. The battles and skirmishes that occurred there in the past 20 years resulted in thousands of deaths of the country‚Äôs ‚Äúsandwich generation,‚Äù causing many of Iraq‚Äôs grandparents to serve as the primary caregivers of their grandchildren, becoming parents for the second time.
.
Magnum photographer @moisessaman photographed the older generation in Mosul as part of a project with @AARP exploring the myriad stories of older persons around the world. You can see a selection of images from Saman's story alongside work by 20 other Magnum photographers on the magnumphotos.com homepage. Link in bio.

‚ÄúThis charming photo shows legendary fashion photographer Richard Avedon and Hollywood superstar dancer Fred Astaire. They are both hiding from the rain and behind a large-format camera with playful smiles and practiced poses, all captured by Magnum‚Äôs co-founder, David ‚ÄòChim‚Äô Seymour. The three men were in Paris with Audrey Hepburn for the making of the film Funny Face, which earned four Academy Award nominations.
.
Avedon‚Äôs obituary in the The New York Times states that his ‚Äòfashion and portrait photographs helped define America's image of style, beauty and culture for the last half-century.‚Äô Astaire‚Äôs obituary noted that his ‚Äòflashing feet and limber legs not only made him America's most popular dancer but also set standards for motion picture musical comedies that have rarely been met and never exceeded.‚Äô
.
Photographers often hide behind their cameras, but rarely do they allow themselves to be photographed in their secretive mode of work. Chim‚Äôs personal engagement with these two fabled stars enabled him to record this delightful encounter, which mocks the idea of hiding behind a camera.‚Äù- Ben Shneiderman, David Seymour‚Äôs nephew (www.davidseymour.com)

Ending soon! @christopherandersonphoto responds to the theme of 'Hidden' with an image and personal text. You can buy the signed print for $100 on shop.magnumphotos.com today only. Link in bio.
.
‚ÄúIn the years following September 11, 2001, I made many trips to Afghanistan. It is a place where much seems hidden.
.
I made this photograph in 2004. These guys were cleaning carpets by shaking out the dust. A Sisyphean task. Dust is one of the things about Afghanistan that I still remember in a visceral way. It was more like beige, talcum powder than dust, seeping into every crack and seam. I imagined that it must be like the dust on the moon (which is where going to Afghanistan felt like at the time). Thousands of years of dry, chalky rock, ground up underfoot until it did not even qualify as sand. .
And it destroyed cameras. At the time, I used Fuji 645 film cameras that had plastic gears in the internal workings. The dust would grind the teeth off the gears. My cameras had to be practically rebuilt after each trip. It became more costly to fix the cameras than to just get new ones.‚Äù - @oh_anderson/Magnum Photos
.
PHOTO: Men shake dust from rugs that were used for a wedding party. Kabul, Afghanistan. 2004.
.
¬© @christopherandersonphoto/Magnum Photos
.
#MAGNUMSQUARE #Hidden #ChristopherAnderson

'The Walls is the oldest unit in the Texas prison, opened in 1849. Beginning in 1982, 562 men have died in its execution chambers. I spent most of 1968 walking around inside the Walls. I used the prints I was making for Conversations with the Dead , most of them in Bruce Davidson‚Äôs darkroom on W. 86th street, to apply for a Guggenheim Fellowship. Afterward the foundation asked if they could have one of the prints. It was The Dominoes Players. In the 1990s, Magnum sent that roll of negatives to a printer for an enlargement and for some reason the printer cut the frame off from the strip of six, frame 36, the last image on the roll. Another decade went by and Magnum decided my original cellulose negative sleeves were not archival so all the prison negatives were moved from the original sleeves into archival paper sleeves. Only the person doing this neglected to look inside the originals for a single separated frame. The old sleeves were burned in the garbage and that was the end of the negative of one of the best pictures I would ever make. I had a single surviving vintage print, and with the arrival of the digital age, it was scanned allowing these small prints to be made. ' - @dannylyonphotos
.
PHOTO: The Dominoes Players. Walls Unit, Huntsville, Texas, USA. 1968. .
¬© @dannylyonphotos/#MagnumPhotos
.

‚ÄúThe Kayan Lahwi people live in the state of Kayah in Myanmar. They are farmers and Buddhists. The Kayan Lahwi women traditionally wear brass rings around their necks. I don't know when this strange custom began. Tourists, Thai or foreign, call these women ‚ÄòLong Neck‚Äô or ‚ÄòGiraffe‚Äô ladies.
.
A small area has been set up for tourists, who have to pay fees to enter. Most of these fees, I fear, go directly to the officials. Back in the 1930s, Englishmen took several ‚ÄòLong Neck‚Äô women to London to show them at a circus. Indeed, when I took a group tour there once, I was horrified to see tourists acting as though they were visiting a circus, a zoo even. .
I went back there alone twice in the early morning. It was then that I could see a piece of their normal, daily life.‚Äù - Hiroji Kubota
.

.

2019 Magnum nominee @nannaheitmann selects an image from her series 'Hiding from Baba Yaga' for the Magnum Square Print Sale in Partnership with @aperturefnd. Heitmann's signed print is available via the link in bio.
.
‚ÄúFrom time immemorial people have sought protection and freedom on the banks of the Yenisei River, whose stream I followed. My journey took me to Tyva Republic, where the Yenisei starts its journey. Arriving in Tyva in southern Siberia left a vivid mark on my memory. On the drive there, as you climb higher and higher, you cross endless forests and mountains. People I passed on the way warned me that although Tyva belongs to Russia it is like the Wild West. Suddenly, as I crossed the mountains, the forests ended, and the land opened out in front of me. I was engulfed by heat. I had entered the Tyva Republic: It felt like entering a different world. .
On the day this picture was taken, a horse race was taking place. It was 43 degrees celsius and the boys had to race 30 km. The young rider shook off the rest of the group. For one moment it felt as though he was riding in the middle of the steppe alone, all by himself.‚Äù - @nannaheitmann
.

The Second Battle of Fallujah started on November 7, 2004, and lasted one and a half months ‚Äì ending just before Christmas Eve. The US-led effort against insurgents in the city was code-named Operation Phantom Fury, and marked the first instance of Coalition military action against a purely insurgent force, since the toppling of the Ba-athist government in 2003.
.
The fighting in the city has since been recognized by many as the most intense urban warfare since the battle of Hu·∫ø city during the Vietnam War. @jeromesessini was in Fallujah embedded with US Marines of Charlie Company, at work in the north eastern sector of the city for one week.

Today on Magnum: On the 15th anniversary of the battle‚Äôs start, Sessini discusses the work he made over that week, his changing feelings about the men he was photographing, and one particular image which represents ‚Äúthe culmination of contempt and dehumanization‚Äù that grows in those at war. Link in bio.

‚ÄúI made this photograph in the 1980s while on assignment in South Carolina for People magazine. While my subject was being taken care of in the barber‚Äôs chair, I made this photograph of a young boy who brought to mind memories of black-owned barbershops.
.
Since I was young, I have always felt that spending time in a black barbershop was equivalent to attending church. Each visit was a shared ritualistic experience among the male clients. Everything was discussed; everyone in the shop was close to the action. It was a place of shared mysteries where grown men spoke amongst themselves, sharing life experiences with young boys in a casual way. It carried great weight for the latter who sat quietly listening and learning. It was an educational experience they‚Äôd keep close to their hearts for the rest of their lives.‚Äù - @elireedmagnum

Magnum photographer @oliviarthur reflects on the notion of being 'Hidden' in Saudi Arabia. Arthur's signed print is available until Friday via the link in bio. .
‚ÄúThe notion of being hidden is pretty well established in Saudi Arabia: most obviously, women inside their abayas and niqabs, but also families behind the high walls of their houses, and young men and women who are separated from each other in public spaces. But the concept of what is hidden also depends on who is looking. Being hidden from one‚Äôs family or from the religious police might also mean being hidden from the rules, and subsequently enjoying the chance to be more liberal.
.
This image was taken in Durrat Al-Arous, a beach town just outside Jeddah where families and young people come on the weekend to relax. Because it is privately owned, the rules of Saudi society don‚Äôt apply and young people can hang out together, wear what they like; women can drive cars or ride bikes. So in a way people are hidden from the rule-makers, and that allows them to be less hidden from one another.‚Äù - @oliviarthur
.
PHOTO: A girl sunbathes in the private beach town of Durrat Al-Arous, where the rules of Saudi society are not enforced. Durrat Al-Arous, Saudi Arabia. 2009.
.
¬© @oliviarthur/#MagnumPhotos
.
